title: English (1879) Wycliffe (Purvey) New Testament
description:
The Wycliffe Bible, attributed to the visionary John Wycliffe and his associates, represents a pivotal moment in the history of Bible translations. Emerging between approximately 1382 and 1395, these translations into Middle English catalyzed the Lollard movement, a significant precursor to the Reformation, challenging numerous doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church.

Long credited to Wycliffe himself, modern scholarship now recognizes the Wycliffe Bible as a collaborative effort, possibly involving figures such as Nicholas of Hereford, John Purvey, and John Trevisa. This series of translations was more than a mere linguistic endeavor; it was an act of religious and social defiance, bringing the scriptures into the vernacular at a time when Latin dominated religious texts. The impact of these translations was profound, democratizing religious knowledge and laying the groundwork for subsequent reformist movements.

Contrary to earlier beliefs that Wycliffe single-handedly produced these texts, the current understanding acknowledges a group effort, reflecting the collective yearning for accessible religious texts. The Wycliffe Bible thus stands not just as a historical artifact but as a testament to the enduring power of collaborative intellectual and spiritual inquiry, significantly influencing the trajectory of Christian thought and practice in the Western world.
